etymology.description: Ideogram; differentiated form of 夗; Shuowen: from flipped 仄 (“to tilt”), indicating something round; unrelated to 丮 in 執/孰.
etymology.interpretation: Originally the same graph as 夗, it was later distinguished to denote a small round object or pellet. The Shuowen view treats it as derived from a flipped 仄, evoking something that tilts or rolls, hence roundness. It is not etymologically related to the 丮-based component seen in 執 and 孰.

examples.chinese: 医生让我每天吃两颗药丸(醫生讓我每天吃兩顆藥丸)。
examples.pinyin: Yīshēng ràng wǒ měitiān chī liǎng kē yàowán.
examples.english: The doctor told me to take two pills each day.

examples.chinese: 汤里有几颗肉丸(湯裡有幾顆肉丸)。
examples.pinyin: Tāng lǐ yǒu jǐ kē ròuwán.
examples.english: There are a few meatballs in the soup.

examples.chinese: 这个岛不过是弹丸之地(這個島不過是彈丸之地)。
examples.pinyin: Zhège dǎo bùguò shì dànwán zhī dì.
examples.english: This island is nothing but a tiny speck of land.
